SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He attributes these symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. He has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. The patient also reports a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive bloating. No chest pain.
• Respiratory: Positive cough. No shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Shows fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is present with flexion and valgus stressing of the knee. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning. He heard a pop in his lower back and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. The pain has been persistent since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. For his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is compliant with his medication.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever or chills.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain. Denies joint pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue to ice the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with metformin, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings have been running on the high side.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been monitoring his knee and managing his symptoms well.
• Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. He reports a tough spring with pollen and moving his daughter to college but is managing well overall.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He feels that his depression is well managed.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. He reports that his blood pressure has been mostly okay.

Regarding his prior lobectomy, he has not experienced any significant issues with shortness of breath, except during periods of high heat and pollen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Reports occasional pounding in the chest during morning runs.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath at rest. Endorses shortness of breath with exertion during morning runs.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   
2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Controlled with Norvasc, despite occasional missed doses on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No significant issues with shortness of breath, chest X-ray normal.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Hill is a 41-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after she was rear-ended in a motor vehicle accident 5 days ago. She has no other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation

EXAM:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit shows a distal phalanx fracture.

IMPRESSION:

Right middle finger distal phalanx fracture.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Tramadol 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain, dispense 8. She is provided a finger splint and will return in 2 weeks for a follow-up x-ray. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She presents today after being unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also notes increased anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was about 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, fever, chills.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Increased anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia presenting with fatigue, fever, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Specialist Referrals: Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Continue taking ferrous sulfate with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to Dr. Howard on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months, which he had not experienced before. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Recently bought a small house.
Adopted, unknown family medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Tylenol (tried for headaches, but discontinued due to lack of efficacy).

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

The patient is informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery, including infection, need for further surgery, wound issues, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, or even death. The patient understands the risks and agrees to proceed with the surgery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female who presents for a follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain in October 2020. The patient experienced chest pain for four days, which resolved after the ER visit. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating and she had difficulty swallowing during that time. The patient has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

The patient denies any heartburn or indigestion at the time of the chest pain. She has not had any abdominal pain or changes in bowel movements. She has been trying to lose weight and has no known family history of GI problems.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Lower Abdomen: No pain or tenderness.
• Examination of Upper Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents for follow-up after an ER visit for chest pain. The chest pain has resolved and she has not had any additional episodes since October 2020. The ER visit ruled out any heart issues. Possible etiologies for her chest pain include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

Given the patient's current asymptomatic status, the plan is to hold off on an EGD and monitor for any additional symptoms. The patient has elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a former 34-week and 3-day-old twin. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She has also seen an orthopedic specialist, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned that individuals with this syndrome may have kidney anomalies.

The patient has normal wet diaper frequency (8-10 per day) and is well-hydrated. She has no family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Katherine is a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. Her eyes appear small, and she has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. She has normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, which can affect several organ systems, including congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract. We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. She reports immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to this wrist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling and bruising in the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports slight tingling in fingers but can still feel them.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 breaths/min
Temp: 97.2°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation throughout. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Bony crepitus present. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively initially with a brace and pain medication (50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours). The patient will undergo surgery for the fracture, followed by a 6-week period of wearing the brace. Physical therapy will be initiated a few weeks after surgery, with an assessment to determine the frequency of sessions. The patient will have a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain worsens or if she experiences any complications following surgery.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg of Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient admits to struggling with maintaining a low-sodium diet.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No other abnormalities.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advised the patient to elevate and rest the affected leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the importance of a low-sodium diet and refer the patient to a nutritionist for further guidance.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap "giving out" while walking. The pain passes quickly and does not last long. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for the pain. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip that involves walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, pulse 72, respirations 16, blood pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
HENT: Reports sore throat and dry cough.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles noted bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination of Chest: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema noted.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide, as well as radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be due to inflammation in the esophagus related to radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds during winter, recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. No history of blood transfusions or blood products.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness or diarrhea.

VITALS

No fever or concerning vitals.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows low IgA levels, but no significant infections or symptoms related to immunodeficiency.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is a common immunodeficiency and most people live their entire life without knowing they have it. The patient was advised to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibodies. The patient was advised to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is rated as 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: Examination of the right elbow reveals moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle with pain to palpation. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and will be provided with a sling to wear while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and to take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during walking.
Genitourinary: Denies any issues.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. 

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring his diet.
- Medical Treatment: He can continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. The onset of his pain began several days ago, described as a sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when present. The patient reports a burning sensation during urination and darker urine at times. He has taken Tylenol for pain, but it has not provided significant relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and has been able to pass them in the past. His father also had a history of kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Abdominal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no evidence of rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient should push fluids to help facilitate urination and passing the stone. I have provided a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for testing. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy. The patient should contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. The patient reports having the ulcer for approximately six weeks, which initially started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister became unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's wife contacted their primary care physician, who started the patient on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has experienced some improvement, but the wound has turned black around the edges, and the patient has been experiencing cramping in the calf muscle. There is also a red streak coming up the front part of the ankle along the inside portion of the calf muscle, which is very hot. The patient has been coughing a lot in the last two days and has had difficulty catching his breath when walking around the house.

The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last A1C was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking with his wife and recently hiked a new trail behind the park.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Patient reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: Patient reports cramping in the calf muscle.
Respiratory: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the ankle and calf.
Neurological: Patient reports diabetic neuropathy.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: within normal limits
Heart rate: within normal limits

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
SKIN: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Foul odor present.
MSK: Pain and swelling in the calf muscle.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed that his right foot ulcer is concerning and will require further intervention. I will order a test to check blood supply for this wound. I will perform a debridement today in the office and obtain a culture to guide antibiotic therapy. The patient will continue his current antibiotics, and we may adjust or add antibiotics based on the culture results. I want the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure proper diabetes management. I will see the patient again in seven days to monitor the progress of the wound and address any additional concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been burning and causing discomfort. Patient denies fever, chills, and joint pain other than typical arthritic pain. He has not had Lyme disease before.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, and joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee discomfort due to tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee and a bull's-eye rash, which raises concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the possibility of Lyme disease and the importance of taking antibiotics as prescribed.

2. Hypertension
- Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
- Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function, as patient expressed concern about potential kidney issues related to Metformin.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
